File.Title: Projections of the Ventral Subiculum to the Amygdala, Septum, and Hypothalamus: A PHAL Anterograde Tract-Tracing Study in the Rat

Abstract.S: The projections of the ventral subiculum are organized differentially along the dorsoventral (or septotemporal) axis of this cortical field, with more ventral regions playing a particularly important role in hippocampal communication with the amygdala, bed nuclei of the stria terminalis (BST), and rostral hypothalamus.
In the present study we re-examined the projection of the ventral subiculum to these regions with the Phaseolus vulgaris leucoagglutinin (PHAL) method in the rat.
The results confirm and extend earlier conclusions based primarily on the autoradiographic method.

Projections from the ventral subiculum course either obliquely through the angular bundle to innervate the amygdala and adjacent parts of the temporal lobe, or follow the alveus and fimbria to the precommissural fornix and medial corticohypothalamic tract.

The major amygdalar terminal field is centered in the posterior basomedial nucleus, while other structures that appear to be innervated include the piriformamygdaloid area, the posterior basolateral, posterior cortical, posterior, central, medial, and intercalated nuclei, and the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract.

Projections from the ventral subiculum reach the BST mainly by way of the precommissural fornix, and provide rather dense inputs to the anterodorsal area as well as the transverse and interfascicular nuclei.

The medial corticohypothalamic tract is the main route taken by fibers from the ventral subiculum to the hypothalamus, where they innervate the medial preoptic area, shell of the ventromedial nucleus, dorsomedial nucleus, ventral premammillary nucleus, and cell-poor zone around the medial mammillary nucleus.

We also observed a rather dense terminal field just dorsal to the suprachiasmatic nucleus that extends dorsally and caudally to fill the subparaventricular zone along the medial border of the anterior hypothalamic nucleus and ventrolateral border of the paraventricular nucleus.

The general pattern of outputs to the hypothalamus and septum is strikingly similar for the ventral subiculum and suprachiasmatic nucleus, the endogenous circadian rhythm generator. o 1992 Wiley-Liss, Inc.

Introduction.S: The subiculum lies near the end of what is thought to be a largely unidirectional sequence of intracortical association projections that link the various subdivisions of the hippocampal formation.

Briefly, the major flow of information through the hippocampal formation takes place through the transversely oriented trisynaptic circuit, which begins with the perforant path projection from the entorhinal area to the dentate gyrus, is relayed to field CA3 of Ammon s horn by the mossy fiber system, and then proceeds to field CAI by way of the Schaffer collateral system.
The major intrahippocampal projections of field CAI are to the subiculum and to the entorhinal area (for review, see Swanson et al., 87).

For its part, the subiculum has one of the most massive and divergent efferent projections of any part of the hippocampal formation, providing inputs to many regions of the telencephalon and diencephalon (see Swanson and Cowan, 75, 77; Meibach and Siegel, 77; Krettek and Price, 78a; Groenewegen et al., 87; Kohler, 90; Witter and Groenewegen, 90; Witter et al., 90).

It is clear that the projections of the subiculum are differentially organized along the dorsoventral (septotemporal, longitudinal) axis of the subiculum, with more ventral regions playing a more important role in hippocampal communication with the amygdala, bed nuclei of the stria terminalis (BST), and hypothalamus.

Thus, for the hypothalamus, dorsal parts of the subiculum give rise to a massive projection that travels in the postcommissural fornix and tends to end preferentially in the mammillary complex, whereas efferent fibers from more ventral parts course through the medial corticohypothalamic tract and are distributed throughout the entire rostrocaudal extent of the medial zone of the hypothalamus, placing this cortical structure in a unique position to influence a wide range of hypothalamic mechanisms (Swanson and Cowan, '75, '77; Meibach and Siegel, '77; Krettek and Price, '78a; Kohler, '90; Witter and Groenewegen, '90; Witter et al., '90).

In addition, it seems likely that projections from the subiculum to the amygdala and bed nuclei of the stria terminalis arise predominantly if not exclusively from its more ventral regions (Swanson and Cowan, '77; Groenewegen et al., '87; Price et al., '87; Witter and Groenewegen, '90).

Projections from the ventral subiculum to the bed nuclei of the stria terminalis and hypothalamus were originally described with the autoradiographic method in the rat (Swanson and Cowan, '75, '77; Meibach and Siegel, '77; Krettek and Price, '78a).

However, these findings are limited because it is often difficult if not impossible to distinguish terminal fields from fibers-of-passage with the method, due to the fact that silver grains rather than axons themselves are actually observed.

In addition, the projection from the subiculum to the amygdala has been thoroughly examined with the autoradiographic method in the monkey (Rosene and Van Hoesen, '77; Aggleton, '86), although no detailed study of this projection has been carried out in the rat.

In view of these limitations, we have decided to re-examine, in the rat, the projection of the ventral subiculum to the amygdala, septum, and hypothalamus with the PHAL anterograde tracer method, which combines all of the advantages of the autoradiographic method with clearly defined injection sites and Golgi-like staining of labeled axons, so that terminal boutons and varicosities can readily be identified and distinguished (see Gerfen and Sawchenko, '84; Wouterlood and Groenegewen, '85).

The results have been interpreted in light of a great deal of new cytoarchitectonic and connectional information that has become available since the original autoradiographic studies, and have also served to clarify differences between regions that lie in the junctional region between the temporal pole of the hippocampal formation and the caudal end of the amygdala (see the accompanying paper by Canteras et al., '92a).

Methods.S: Eight adult male Sprague-Dawley rats received an injection of Phaseolus vulgaris leucoagglutinin (PHAL; Vector Laboratories) into ventral parts of the subiculum.

Each animal was anesthetized with tribromoethanol, and a single iontophoretic injection of a 2.5% solution of PHAL in 0.01 M sodium phosphate-buffered saline (pH 7.4) was made through a stereotaxically positioned glass micropipette (tip diameter 10 km) by applying a +8 PA current, pulsed at 7-second intervals, and provided by a constant-current source (Midgard Electronics, Model CS3) for a period of 20 minutes.
Postinjection survival times for all experiments ranged from 14 to 16 days.
The animals were perfused and the brains were processed according to procedures described in detail elsewhere (Canteras et al., '92a).

Briefly, each animal was deeply anesthetized with tribromoethanol and perfused transcardially with a solution of 4.0% paraformaldehyde in 0.1 M sodium borate buffer at pH 9.5; the brains were removed immediately and postfixed overnight in the same fixative containing 10% sucrose.
Four one-in-five series of 30-km-thick frozen sections were cut with a sliding microtome in the frontal plane and collected from the septa1 region rostrally to the middle of the midbrain caudally.
An additional series of sections was collected through the level of the ventral subiculum, and "quick-stained'' for confirmation of injection site placement (see Simerly and Swanson, '88).
One complete series of sections was processed for immunohistochemistry with an antiserum directed against PHAL (Dako Laboratories) at a dilution of 1:1,000.

The antigen-antibody complex was localized by using a variation of the avidin-biotin complex system (ABC; Hsu and Raine, '81; Hsu et al., '811, with a commercially available kit (ABC Elite Kit, Vector Laboratories).
The sections were mounted on gelatin-coated slides, and treated with osmium tetroxide to enhance the visibility of the reaction product.
Slides were then dehydrated and coverslipped with DPX.
An adjacent series was always stained with thionin to serve as a reference series for cytoarchitectonic purposes.
Sections were examined with a Leitz Laborlux D microscope with both brightand darkfield illumination.

The PHAL-labeled cells in the injection sites, as well as the distribution of anterograde labeled fibers were plotted with the aid of a camera lucida onto maps prepared from adjacent Nissl-stained sections.
For illustration purposes, the distribution of anterogradely labeled fibers was transferred onto a series of standard drawings of the rat brain (Swanson, '92).

Results.S: The parameters used for making the iontophoretic injections described above resulted in discrete injection sites, typically with hundreds of clearly labeled (PHAL-immunoreactive) neurons.

TTE.S: In five experiments the injection was virtually confined to the temporal pole of the subiculum.
The location and approximate extent of each of these injection sites are plotted on an unfolded map of the rat hippocampal formation from Swanson et al. ('78) (Fig. 1).
Each of these five experiments labeled a similar pattern of projections.

Since the injection site in experiment SUB-16 encompassed a relatively broad extent of the ventral subiculum (Figs. 1, 21, and a correspondingly dense pattern of fibers was labeled, this experiment was used to illustrate in detail the efferent projections of the ventral subiculum to the amygdala, septum, and hypothalamus (Fig. 3).
Projections to the amygdala
One group of labeled fibers courses directly from the injection site to the amygdala by crossing the angular bundle (Fig. 3P).

At caudal levels of the amygdala, these fibers establish an impressive plexus in the posterior part of the basomedial nucleus, and a smaller group of labeled axons appears to end in the caudalmost parts of the posterior subdivision of the basolateral nucleus, the posterior nucleus, the posterior cortical nucleus, and the piriformamygdaloid area (Fig. 31-M; see Canteras et al., '92a for subdivisions of the amygdala used here).
It is important to emphasize that the posterior part of the basomedial nucleus is by far the most densely labeled region in the amygdala in any of our experiments.

As the stria terminalis leaves the amygdala, a number of labeled fibers course dorsally to supply a dense terminal field to the caudalmost end of the central nucleus and adjacent regions of the caudoputamen (Fig. 31-K).
It is also interesting to note that a very small number of fibers in this area leave the amygdala by way of the stria terminalis (Fig. 3J,K).

A moderate number of fibers continue rostrally through the amygdala, providing along the way clear inputs to the central nucleus, the medial nucleus, the intercalated nuclei, and the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract.

Within the central nucleus, the caudalmost pole of the lateral subdivision receives a particularly dense plexus of fibers, and proceeding more rostrally, the labeled axons preferentially innervate the capsular subdivision, and to a lesser extent ventral parts of the medial subdivision (Fig. 3F-K).

The medial nucleus of the amygdala receives a moderate number of anterogradely labeled fibers, which are located mainly within the anterodorsal and posteroventral subdivisions, clearly tending to avoid the posterodorsal subdivision (Fig. 3F-K).

The intercalated nuclei adjacent to the central and medial nuclei also receive a moderate number of axons, which display a highly branched pattern and give rise to a fairly large number of terminal boutons (Fig. 3F,G).
Anterogradely labeled axons from the ventral subiculum appear to provide only a very sparse input to the lateral and basolateral nuclei (Fig. 3F-L).
Furthermore, only a few labeled axons were observed in the anterior part of the basomedial nucleus (Fig. 3E-I), in sharp contrast to the dense input to the posterior part of the nucleus.

Throughout the entire extent of the amygdala, a small number of labeled fibers take a lateral course to the piriform area and especially to the dorsal endopiriform nucleus just deep to it (Fig. 3D-M).
In addition, some labeled fibers also appear to end in the claustrum as well as in deep layers of the agranular insular and perirhinal areas.

At rostral levels of the amygdala, a sparse contingent of labeled fibers enters the substantia innominata and courses toward caudal parts of the BST; in addition, a very few labeled axons were observed surrounding the dorsal border of the supraoptic nucleus on their way toward the preoptic region (Fig. 3E-F).
In none of our experiments with PHAL injections in the ventral subiculum were any labeled fibers observed in the contralateral amygdala.
Projections through the fimbria

The second major group of labeled axons that leaves the ventral subiculum courses through the alveus and fimbria, and on reaching the septum divides into two components, the precommissural fornix and the medial corticohypothalamic tract.
Precommissural fornix.

As the fimbria approaches the caudal end of the septal region, these axons fan out to run through (and give rise to many terminal boutons within) the ventral lateral septal nucleus and adjacent parts of the intermediate lateral septal and septofimbrial nuclei (Fig.3A-D).
The rostral continuation of the pathway will be briefly described below.

Here it is appropriate to point out that many of these fibers course in a more ventral direction to innervate the bed nuclei of the stria terminalis (BST) (Fig. 3B-D), although a very small number of fibers may reach this complex by way of the stria terminalis and/or the ansa peduncularis (see above).

In addition, several labeled fibers from the precommissural fornix also take a ventral course just rostral the anterior commissure and appear to enter the preoptic region (Fig. 3B), as discussed below.

In the anterior division of the BST (for subdivisions see Ju and Swanson, '891, the majority of labeled fibers end within the anterodorsal area adjacent to the ventral part of the lateral septal nucleus (Fig. 3B,C).
Only a few axons continue laterally toward the anterolateral area, which contained only scattered fibers and terminal boutons i Fig. 3B-D).

A moderate number of labeled axons also reach the anteroventral area of the BST, either by taking a ventromedial course rostral to the anterior commissure (Fig. 3B), or by running ventrolaterally through the anterodorsal area, immediately caudal to the anterior commissure (Fig. 3D).

Within the anteroventral area, the labeled fibers appear to end primarily in the dorsomedial, dorsolateral, magnocellular, and ventral nuclei (Fig. 3C,D); interestingly, they tend to avoid the parastrial nucleus, which has been regarded as part of the preoptic region (Simerly et al., '84; Ju and Swanson, '89) and lies immediately ventral to the medial aspect of this part of the BST (Fig. 3B-D).

At more caudal levels, a moderate number of labeled axons take a ventral route toward the posterior division of the BST, where they give rise to dense terminal fields within the interfascicular and transverse nuclei, but almost no fibers in the principal nucleus (Figs. 3E, 4A).

It is important to point out that it is not possible in our material to be certain whether scattered fibers from the BST continue on to end in various parts of the preoptic region, as their orientation would suggest, or whether they are confined to the BST.

Finally, a small number of labeled fibers were found in the contralateral BST, particularly in regions that are the most densely innervated ipsilaterally, including the anterodorsal area, and the interfascicular and transverse nuclei.
These fibers reach the contralateral side of the brain by crossing through the ventral hippocampal commissure (Fig. 3E).
The rostrally directed group of precommissural fibers continues on to the rostral pole of the septal region in the ventrolateral corner of the lateral septal nucleus.

Many of these fibers course ventrally to innervate the nucleus accumbens, and to a much lesser extent the fundus of the striatum and olfactory tubercle (Fig. 3A), while rostral to the septal regon (not examined here; see Swanson and Cowan, '79; Swanson, '81; Jay and Witter, '91), other fibers innervate parts of the cellular layer of the anterior olfactory nucleus, as well as the prelimbic, infralimbic, and medial orbital areas of the cortex.
Medial corticoh.ypypothalanzic tract.
These fibers diverge from the fornix in the anterodorsomedial tip of the hypothalamus, between the paraventricular nuclei of the thalamus and hypothalamus (Figs. 3E, 4A).
No labeled fibers were observed in the postcommissural fornix in any of our experiments with PHAL injections confined to the ventralmost part of the subiculum.

The medial corticohypothalamic tract, whose only known source of fibers is the ventral subiculum, in fact gwes rise to two branches, one to the thalamus and the other to the hypothalamus (Swanson et al., '87).

Labeled fibers to the thalamus from the ventral tip of the subiculum end throughout the length of the paraventricular nucleus and nucleus reuniens, and a few axons also appear to innervate the parataenial nucleus and the lateral habenula (Fig. 3E-M).
The much larger hypothalamic branch of this tract predominantly innervates cell groups of the medial zone, contributing relatively few axons to the periventricular and lateral zones.

At rostral levels of the preoptic region, labeled fibers are distributed mainly within undifferentiated parts of the medial preoptic area and to a lesser extent in the anteroventral preoptic nucleus; very few axons enter the anteroventral periventricular and the median preoptic nuclei (Fig. 3B,C).

Proceeding caudally, one finds a somewhat more dense plexus of labeled fibers in undifferentiated parts of the medial preoptic area, as well as in the lateral subdivision of the medial preoptic nucleus (Fig. 3D,E).

This nucleus also contains a moderate number of labeled axons in ventral and caudal regions of the medial subdivision, whereas the central subdivision is virtually free of anterograde labeling (Fig. 3D,E).
Fibers from the ventral subiculum tend to avoid the parastrial and anterodorsal preoptic nuclei (Fig. 3B-D).

As noted above, a moderate contingent of fibers from the precommissural fornix also appears to project to the preoptic region, and the extent to which fibers in each of the preoptic cell groups travel, through the medial corticohypothalamic tract and/or the precommissural fornix could not be determined.

In the anterior hypothalamic region, anterogradely labeled fibers from the ventral subiculum generate a dense terminal field just dorsal to the suprachiasmatic nucleus (Figs. 3E, 4B) that extends dorsally and caudally to fill the subparaventricular zone (of Watts et al., 87) along the medial border of the anterior hypothalamic nucleus and the ventrolateral border of the paraventricular nucleus (Figs. 3F,G, 4C).

The paraventricular nucleus itself (see Swanson and Simmons, 89 for subdivisions) is traversed by small fascicles of the medial corticohypothalamic tract (Fig. 4C), which are also obvious within the anterior periventricular and suprachiasmatic nuclei (Fig. 4B).
However, both the Paraventricular nucleus and the other periventricular nuclei appear to contain only a few fibers bearing terminal boutons (Figs. 3E-H, 4B,C).

Caudal to the suprachiasmatic nucleus, the retrochiasmatic area receives a moderately dense projection from the ventral subiculum, and a sparse contingent of labeled fibers was also observed coursing more laterally through and to the anterior hypothalamic area (Fig. 3F).

The dense plexus of labeled axons and terminal boutons in the subparaventricular zone continues caudally toward the tuberal region to surround mainly dorsal and medial aspects of the ventromedial nucleus (Fig. 3G-K).
A moderate number of these axons cross through lateral parts of the arcuate nucleus (Fig. 3H,I), although few of them actually give rise to terminal boutons within the nucleus itself.
At the tuberal level, a number of fibers course dorsally to provide a moderately dense terminal plexus within the dorsomedial nucleus (Fig. 31-K).

A smaller number of labeled axons at this level also run near the lateral and ventral borders of the ventromedial nucleus, as well as through rostral parts of the ventrolateral subdivision of this nucleus (Fig. 3H-J).

In addition to innervating the cell-sparse shell around the ventromedial nucleus, some fibers from the ventral subiculum also appear to end in caudal parts of both the central and the ventrolateral subdivisions of this nucleus (Figs. 3J,K, 4D).

Labeled fibers from the medial corticohypothalamic tract continue on to the mammillary region, where they provide moderately dense inputs to the posterior periventricular nucleus, the ventral premammillary nucleus, ventral regions of the posterior nucleus, and the fiber capsule around the outside of the medial mammillary nucleus (Fig. 360).
In fact, the results of our experiments indicate that the ventral subiculum innervates the posterior periventricular nucleus more densely than any other structure in the periventricular zone.
In addition, we also observed at this level a few labeled fibers that appear to end in both the dorsal and ventral parts of the tuberomammillary nucleus (Fig. 3L,M).

The caudalmost projection of the ventral subiculum appears to consist of a few axons coursing through the posterior hypothalamic nucleus that continue on to end in rostralmost parts of the periaqueductal gray, and the medial subdivision of the supramammillary nucleus (Fig. 3N,O).
Although the output of the ventral subiculum to the hypothalamus is largely ipsilateral, a small number of fibers were reliably found on the contralateral side of the brain.
In general, the contralateral projections are directed to areas that contained the densest plexus of fibers ipsilaterally.

Most of the labeled fibers cross the midline in the ventral hippocampal commissure, the supraoptic commissures, and in regions dorsal to the third ventricle, either through the nucleus reuniens, or more posteriorly, through the supramammillary decussation.

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION

The results of the present study confirm and extend what was previously known about projections from the ventral subiculum to the amygdala, septum, and hypothalamus, and are based on the PHAL method, whose now well-known advantages were referred to in the Introduction.
Furthermore, they appear to be reliable to the extent that they were confirmed in all five experiments with injections centered in the ventral subiculum.
Nevertheless, there are two major sources of confusion that render difficult the comparison of our results with the earlier literature: nomenclature and the geometry of the hippocampal formation.

In a general way, it has been appreciated at least since the time of Lorente de NO ('34) that there are clear differences in the cytoarchitecture of the subiculum along both the septotemporal and proximodistal (or mediolateral; transverse) axes, and it has since been shown that these differences are reflected in the connections of various regions of this cortical field (Swanson and Cowan, '75, '77; Swanson et al., '87; Witter and Groenewegen, '90; Witter et al., '90).

However, problems have arisen because different authors have defined in different ways the borders of the subiculum, with hippocampal field CAI on one side (proximally) and with the presubiculum on the other (distally); and because the relative positions of lesions or injection sites are difficult to appreciate in relation to the two cardinal axes, in sections cut in any of the standard planes of section, due to the highly folded nature of the hippocampal formation (see Swanson et al., '87).
lherefore, it is important to point out that we have followed Blackstad's ('56) definition of the borders of the subiculum, as have most workers since that time.
There appears to be little remaining confusion about the distal border of the subiculum with the presubiculum (whose layer I1 is so distinct).

It is the proximal border, with hippocampal field CAI, that is so problematic, especially ventrally where distinctions between the two cortical areas become progressively less clear as the temporal pole (and amygdala) is approached.

Nevertheless, we have chosen to maintain the two criteria for the boundary that are relatively clear dorsally: the disappearance of the stratum oriens associated with field CAI at the proximal border of the subiculum, and the disappearance of the dense superficial layer of field CAI pyramidal cells at the proximal border of the subiculum (see Fig. 2 in Lorente de NO, '34; and Fig. 2 in Blackstad, '56).
The "prosubiculum" as originally defined by the Vogts ('19), Rose ('261, and Lorente de NO ('34) clearly falls within the subiculum as defined by Blackstad ('56).

The second major problem associated with interpreting our results-the complex geometry of each hippocampal field-has been addressed by plotting the location of injection sites on an unfolded map of the hippocampal formation (Swanson et al., '781, which allows topographical relationships to be appreciated much more clearly than in sections through the structure (see Fig. l), and by producing injection sites that were small enough to avoid spurious labeling of cell bodies in adjacent cortical (or amygdalar) areas that would label pathways not arising in the subiculum as defined here.
With these caveats in mind, we can now discuss the relationship of our findings to the earlier literature, as well as their functional implications (Fig. 5 ) .
Input to the temporal lobe
Projections from the subiculum to the amygdala have been described in the rat (Ottersen, '82; Groenewegen et al., '87), cat (Russchen, '821, and monkey (Rosene and Van Hoesen, '77; Aggleton, '86).
In all three species, neurons located more ventrally appear to generate this projection.
Our results indicate that efferent fibers from the ventral subiculum reach the amygdala by crossing obliquely through the angular bundle.

These axons appear to innervate most densely caudal regions of the amygdala, where they provide a massive input to the posterior part of the basomedial nucleus, and a less dense input to nearby regions, including the caudal pole of the posterior part of the basolateral nucleus, the posterior nucleus, the posterior cortical nucleus, and the piriform-amygdaloid area.
The present study is the first to document a projection to the posterior basomedial nucleus, by far the densest target of ventral subicular outputs within the amygdala.
Using fluorogold as a retrograde tracer, we were able to confirm this projection, which also appears to contain fibers that may arise in adjacent, ventral parts of field CA1 (N.S.
Canteras and L.W.
Swanson, unpublished observations).

A projection from the ventral subiculum to the posterior cortical nucleus has also been reported by Ottersen ('821, in the rat, using horseradish peroxidase (HRP) as a retrograde tracer; according to this author ventral parts of field CA1 project more densely to this nucleus.

A smaller number of efferent fibers from the ventral subiculum continue rostrally though the amygdala, providing inputs mainly to the central nucleus, the medial nucleus, the adjacent intercalated nuclei, and the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract.

In the central nucleus, a relatively dense terminal field was observed in the caudalmost pole of the lateral subdivision, whereas at more rostra1 levels labeled axons were preferentially located in the capsular subdivision.
In the medial nucleus, the projection was mainly directed to the anterodorsal and the posteroventral subdivisions.

In agreement with the present results, Ottersen ('82) reported a few retrogradely labeled cells in the ventral subiculum following injections of HRP into the medial nucleus or the central nucleus of the rat amygdala.

While a projection from the ventral subiculum to the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract has not been specifically described in the past, Groenewegen et al. ('87) did illustrate without comment anterogradely labeled fibers in this nucleus after injections of PHAL into the ventral subiculum of the rat.

In all of the experiments analyzed in the present study, the basolateral and lateral nuclei of the amygdala received only a few labeled fibers, except for the caudal pole of the posterior basolateral nucleus.

In his studies on the connections of the amygdala in the rat, Ottersen ('82) reported only a few retrogradely labeled neurons in the ventral subiculum after injections of HRP into the basolateral or lateral nuclei, although the temporal third of field CA1 in these experiments did contain a larger number of labeled neurons.
A projection from the temporal third of field CAI to the basolateral nucleus has also been reported recently in the rat with the PHAL method (Van Groen and Wyss, '90).

In contrast to what has just been discussed for the rat, there is as yet no evidence in the monkey (Rosene and Van Hoesen, '77; Aggleton, '86) or cat (Russchen, '82) for a direct projection from field CA1 to the amygdala.

Another component of the hippocampal formation, the lateral entorhinal area, also provides a dense input to the amygdala that is especially directed to the lateral and basolateral nuclei (Wyss, '81; Swanson and Kohler, '86).
In view of what has been discussed thus far, projections from the hippocampal formation to the amygdala appear to have a certain topographic organization in the rat.

Thus, the lateral and basolateral nuclei receive inputs mainly from the lateral entorhinal area and/or temporal regions of field CA1, whereas the ventral subiculum projects especially densely to the posterior part of the basomedial nucleus.

The latter also receives a very dense projection from the lateral nucleus of the amygdala (Krettek and Price, '78b), and is thus in a position to integrate cortical information known to converge upon the lateral nucleus (see Ottersen, '82; Price et al., '87) with information processed in the hippocampal formation.

It should also be pointed out that the posterior basomedial nucleus shares several targets in common with the ventral subiculum, including the nucleus accumbens, the bed nuclei of the stria terminalis, the ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus, and the ventral premammillary nucleus (Krettek and Price, '78a).

In view of evidence presented here that the posterior basomedial nucleus is an important relay for information generated in the hippocampal formation, a detailed analysis of the projections of this nucleus with the PHAL method would clearly be useful.

Before we compare results on the projections of the ventral subiculum to the amygdala in the rat with what has been reported for the cat (Russchen, '82) and monkey (Rosene and Van Hoesen, '77; Aggleton, '86), it is necessary to point out that correlations of this type should be viewed with some caution until homologies between various amygdalar cell groups are clarified more fully in different species.

Be that as it may, in the cat, Russchen ('82) found retrogradely labeled neurons in the ventral subiculum after tracer injections in the central nucleus, in the posterolateral part of the posterior cortical nucleus, or in the latter combined with the basomedial nucleus, in agreement with our PHAL studies in the rat.

Furthermore, Russchen ('82) found no evidence of retrograde labeling in the ventral subiculum following tracer injections in the lateral or basolateral nuclei of the amygdala, which is also in essential agreement with our results.

Autoradiographic studies in the monkey (Rosene and Van Hoesen, '77; Aggleton, '86) indicate that the ventral subiculum projects most densely to medial and caudal regions of the parvicellular part of the basal nucleus, which has been said to correspond to what we call here in the rat the posterior basolateral nucleus (see Price et al., '87).

The autoradiographic evidence also indicates that the ventral subiculum in the monkey projects less densely to the central and medial nuclei of the amygdala, as well as to the periamygdaloid cortex, which corresponds to the piriformamygdaloid area plus the lateral part of the posterior cortical nucleus in the subdivision scheme we have adopted here for the rat (compare Price et al., '87 with Canteras et al., '92a).

Based on our results, the projection of the ventral subiculum upon the amygdala is very similar in the monkey and rat if we regard (as seems plausible to us) medial areas of the parvicellular basal nucleus in the monkey as homologous to the posterior basomedial nucleus in the rat.
However, Price et al. ('87) suggested that the posterior basomedial nucleus of the present account corresponds to the accessory basal nucleus in the monkey.
The present connectional information suggests that further work is needed to evaluate this homology.

For the sake of completeness, it should be mentioned that we confirmed the well-known topographic input from the subiculum to the entorhinal area (for review see Swanson et al., '87), as well as the recently described (Groenewegen et al., '87; Witter et al., '88) input to the dorsal endopiriform nucleus; in addition, labeled fibers that appear to be related in a general way to these projections were observed in the cellular layers of adjacent olfactory cortical regions, including the piriform area, and area TR, as well as in the claustrum, and deep layers of the agranular insular and perirhinal areas (see also Fig. 3 in Groenewegen et al., '87).
Input to the septum

Projections from the hippocampal formation to the bed nuclei of the stria terminalis appear to arise almost exclusively from neurons in more ventral parts of the subiculum (Swanson et al., '871, and reach the BST mainly by way of the precommissural component of the fornix.
The projection from the ventral subiculum to the BST described here is similar to our earlier observations in the rat (Swanson and Cowan, '77) using the autoradiographic method.
However, the PHAL study here provides a more thorough analysis in terms of inputs to the various subdivisions of the BST recently described by Ju and Swanson ('89).

In the anterior division of the BST, anterogradely labeled fibers and terminal boutons from the ventral subiculum were distributed preferentially to the anterodorsal area, and to a lesser extent the anteroventral area, whereas the anterolateral area contained only a few PHAL-immunoreactive axons.

In the posterior division of the BST, the interfascicular and the transverse nuclei receive a dense plexus of fibers, which tend to avoid the adjoining principal nucleus, where only a very few anterogradely labeled fibers were observed.
In addition, the contralateral BST contained a few labeled fibers that were particularly obvious in regions that appear to be more densely innervated on the ipsilateral side of the brain.
The BST receives massive inputs from the ventral subiculum and from many parts of the amygdala (see Krettek and Price, '78a; Canteras et al., '92a).

From this point of view, the ventral subiculum is more like adjacent parts of the amygdala than the rest of the hippocampal formation, especially when its projections to the hypothalamus are also taken into account (Swanson et al., '87).

However, it is important to note that the posterior nucleus of the amygdala, which lies directly adjacent to the ventral subiculum, gives rise to a distinct pattern of projections to the BST and hypothalamus (see Canteras et al., '92a), as discussed below.

Thus, the ventral subiculum projects massively to the transverse and interfascicular nuclei in the posterior division (like the posterior cortical nucleus, and several parts of the medial nucleus of the amygdala), whereas the posterior nucleus of the amygdala projects massively to the principal nucleus of the posterior division of the BST (like the posterodorsal part of the medial nucleus of the amygdala).

It is thus interesting to note that specific populations of cells in the BST (such as the transverse and interfascicular nuclei) may be directly influenced by information processed within both the amygdala and the trisynaptic circuit of the hippocampal formation.

As suggested by previous autoradiographic studies, the projections from the BST include a very widespread input to the hypothalamus, as well as inputs to the nucleus accumbens, to several parts of the thalamus, and to widespread parts of the brainstem (Swanson and Cowan, '79; Holstege et al., '85).

However, to provide reliable clues about the possible functional significance of the direct projection from the hippocampal formation to specific parts of the BST, it will be necessary to characterize the specific patterns of outputs from these particular cell groups in the BST.

As illustrated in Figure 3, fibers from the precommissural fornix also continue rostrally to and through ventral and intermediate parts of the lateral septal nucleus as well as to the nucleus accumbens.

This projection, along with its continuation to the anterior olfactory nucleus and the medial prefrontal region is well known (see Swanson and Cowan, '77; Swanson, '81; Groenewegen et al., '87; Jay and Witter, '91).
Input to the hypothalamus

Massive projections from the ventral subiculum to the hypothalamus have been reported with both anterograde (Swanson and Cowan, '75, '77; Meibach and Siegel, '77; Krettek and Price, '78a; Kohler, '90; Witter and Groenewegen, '90) and retrograde tracing techniques (Berk and Finkelstein, '81; Zaborsky, '82; Ono et al., '85; Simerly and Swanson, '86; Fahrbach et al., '89).

Efferent fibers from the ventral subiculum reach the hypothalamus primarily by way of the medial corticohypothalamic tract, and to a much lesser extent through the precommissural component of the fornix and the ansa peduncularis (after passing through the amygdala).
In a study of subicular projections to the hypothalamus with the PHAL, method, Kohler ('90) reported labeled axons in the postcommissural fornix as it passes through the lateral hypothalamic area.
However, no labeled fibers coursing through the postcommissural fornix were observed in any of our experiments.

This discrepancy would easily be explained if his injection sites spread to involve somewhat more dorsal parts of this cortical field, which are known to project to the hypothalamus by way of the postcommissural fornix (Swanson and Cowan, '75, '77; Meibach and Siegel, '77; Witter and Groenewegen, '90; Witter et al., '90).

This interpretation is strengthened by the fact that labeled fibers in the postcommissural fornix have not been reported in previous autoradiographic studies of the ventralmost parts of the subiculum (Swanson and Cowan, '77; Meibach and Siegel, '77; Krettek and Price, '78a).

We have confirmed an extensive, largely ipsilateral projection from the ventral subiculum to the entire rostrocaudal extent of the hypothalamus that appears to be mainly directed to regions lying in the medial zone (Swanson and Cowan, '75, '77; Meibach and Siegel, '77; Krettek and Price, '78a).

In the preoptic region, undifferentiated parts of the medial preoptic area, as well as the lateral subdivision of the medial preoptic nucleus, receive a dense input, whereas a smaller number of labeled fibers end in the anteroventral periventricular nucleus and in the medial subdivision of the medial preoptic nucleus.

As suggested by the results of previous retrograde tracer studies (Berk and Finkelstein, '81; Simerly and Swanson, '86), neurons in the temporal pole that project to the medial zone of the preoptic region lie chiefly in the medial and posterior nuclei of the amygdala, as well as in ventral parts of the subiculum.

However, in contrast to what was just described for the subiculum, the posterodorsal part of the medial nucleus and the posterior nucleus of the amygdala appear to project much more heavily to the anteroventral periventricular nucleus, as well as to the medial subdivision of the medial preoptic nucleus (Simerly et al., '89; Canteras et al., '92a).
This is important because each cell group in the medial preoptic region gives rise to a distinct pattern of projections.

Thus, the medial subdivision of the medial preoptic nucleus and the anteroventral periventricular nucleus project heavily to all of the parvicellular neurosecretory regions of the periventricular zone of the hypothalamus, whereas the undifferentiated regions of the medial preoptic area and the lateral subdivision of the medial preoptic nucleus give rise to massive projections to the septal region and the brainstem (Simerly and Swanson, '88).

In the anterior hypothalamic region, the ventral subiculum provides a very dense plexus of fibers and terminal boutons to a narrow vertical region that lies between the anterior hypothalamic nucleus and the periventricular zone, a region that we had earlier referred to as the subparaventricular zone (Watts et al., '87).
Very few terminal boutons were found within the suprachiasmatic nucleus itself.

As previously reported in the autoradiographic studies (Swanson and Cowan, '75, '77; Meibach and Siegel, '77; Krettek and Price, '78a), at the tuberal level of the hypothalamus, the ventral subiculum provides a dense terminal field to the cell-sparse "shell" surrounding the ventromedial nucleus, particularly in regions where this nucleus adjoins the dorsomedial nucleus and the periventricular zone.
In addition, we found that a number of these fibers also end within the cellular "core" of caudal regions of the central and ventrolateral subdivisions of this nucleus.
We also found at tuberal levels a moderate projection to all parts of the dorsomedial nucleus.

This cell group may represent an important interface between the ventral subiculum and parvicellular neurons that secrete hormones into the hypophyseal portal system, since it provides a massive projection to neurosecretory regions of the paraventricular nucleus, the anterior periventricular nucleus, and the arcuate nucleus, which are known to contain most of the neurosecretory cells directly involved in neuroendocrine control mechanisms (see Swanson, '871, and according to our observations appear to receive only a sparse direct innervation from the ventral subiculum itself.

This implies that the ventral subiculum has little if any direct influence on the perikarya of neurosecretory motoneurons, although clearly, their dendrites may extend into the terminal fields described.

Immediately caudal to the tuberal region we also found a moderately dense projection to the posterior periventricular nucleus, the ventral premammillary nucleus, and ventral parts of the posterior hypothalamic nucleus.

The projection to the ventral premammillary nucleus has been reported previously with the autoradiographic method (Swanson and Cowan, '77; Meibach and Siegel, '77; Krettek and Price, '78a), and we have shown recently that this nucleus in turn provides massive inputs to the periventricular subdivision of the paraventricular nucleus, all parts of the periventricular nucleus, and the arcuate nucleus (Canteras et al., '92b).
Therefore, it may represent another gateway for the ventral subiculum to influence neurosecretory motoneurons.

In complete agreement with previous autoradiographic studies (Swanson and Cowan, '77; Meibach and Siegel, ,771, we also observed at the level of the mammillary complex that the ventral subiculum gives rise to a dense plexus of fibers in the cell-free region surrounding the medial mammillary nucleus.

On the other hand, the cellular "core" of this nucleus, which appears to receive very few labeled fibers in the experiments analyzed here, clearly is the major hypothalamic target of neurons in the dorsal subiculum (Swanson and Cowan, '75, '77; Meibach and Siegel, '77; Witter and Groenewegen, '90; Witter et al., '90).

Since the cell-free zone contains the distal dendrites of medial mammillary neurons (see Ramon y Cajal, '111, the evidence suggests that the dorsal subiculum innervates the cell bodies of medial mammillary neurons whereas the ventral subiculum innervates distal parts of their dendrites.

Hypothalamic regions that receive direct inputs from the ventral subiculum are thought to play an important role in the initiation of motivated or goal-oriented behavior and in the regulation of endocrine responses (see Swanson, '87).

The importance of these observations is further strengthened by the fact that this hippocampal field appears to relay information from widespread cortical areas (see Introduction), and is therefore in a position to modulate important anticipatory adjustments to endocrine and behavioral responses integrated at the level of the hypothalamus.

One example of the possible involvement of the ventral subiculum in anticipatory adjustments of hormone levels was reported by Fischette et al. ( 801, who disrupted the diurnal rhythm of plasma adrenal glucocorticoid levels after lesions that selectively interrupt the medial corticohypothalamic tract, which arises almost exclusively from the ventral subiculum.
The diurnal rhythm of plasma glucocorticoids is also regulated by the suprachiasmatic nucleus, the endogenous circadian rhythm generator (for references see Watts et al., 87).

One of the most interesting features to emerge from the present study is that the pattern of projections from the ventral subiculum to the septum and hypothalamus overlaps almost precisely with the efferent projections of the suprachiasmatic nucleus (Watts et al., 87).

Thus, it is tempting to suggest that basal forebrain circuits controlling behavioral state and neuroendocrine responses receive convergent inputs from the suprachiasmatic nucleus and the ventral subiculum, the former concerned with providing a circadian bias, and the latter with anticipatory biases related to the previous experience of the animal.

In conclusion, the present observations expand in a number of ways what has been reported previously about the projections of the ventral subiculum to the amygdala, septum, and hypothalamus, providing further insights into possible hippocampal influences on endocrine and behavioral responses.

However, it is important to emphasize that our experimental observations are limited to the outputs of the temporal end (ventralmost pole) of the subiculum; thus, further work is required to provide a more complete picture of the projections of the cortical field examined in the present work.
